Aims and Objectives

This tutorial is intended to introduce basic principles and commonly used tools for the analysis of mass-spectrometry proteomics data including:

  • Using a mass spectrometry "search engine" to identify proteins from mass spectra
  • Using online tools to analyze the identified proteins in terms of protein networks
  • Using online tools to analyze the identified proteins in terms of their functions and sub-cellular locations

The tutorial is centred around several proteomics case studies taken from the scientific literature (case studies tab). Mass-spectrometry data (peak lists) are provided for each case study to be searched against a sequence database using a search engine. Protein networks and functions will then be analyzed using online tools.

Instructions

  • Select a case-study for analysis
    • Read through the case studies, and select one for analysis.
  • Search the mass-spectra against a sequence database
    • Download the peak list files provided for each case study. See here for guidance on peak list file formats
    • Use the Mascot or Tandem search engine to identify proteins. See here for guidance
    • Run the search and extract the proteins from the output file
  • Functionally analyze the identified proteins using the Gene Ontology tool GOrilla
    • To identify enriched Gene Ontology categories, analyze the proteins in GOrilla (See here)
  • Network analysis using STRING
    • Open the downloaded results and select identified proteins (gene_symbol)
    • To identify relevant protein networks, analyze the proteins in STRING (See here)
